Dear Ms. Harding :
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505-2-b
Section At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with the terms
Description of the contract required by R 400.12510, continues to reside in a safe
and acceptable environment, and is managing expenditures.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Living area has rats.
Investigation I completed an onsite inspection on 11/21/2022. There was no
evidence of rats at the facility. The facility was appropriately
4

maintained, and no safety hazards were noted. I interviewed Staff 2
who reported the agency does have a pest control company come into
the facility for inspections on a monthly basis. The most recent 3
months of inspections were received to provide confirmation and did
not document rats. I interviewed Staff 1 who is the caseworker for
Complainant 1. Staff 1 stated Complainant 1 later recanted his
allegations other than the issue of the agency withholding the stipend
checks for the youth. I interviewed Staff 3 who reported everything is
going well and expressed no environmental concerns. Staff 3 is the
therapist for participants in this program.
I interviewed Youth A by telephone on 02/16/2023 and Youth A
confirmed he had not seen any rats in the facility.
Analysis There is no evidence of rats being found in the facility. The facility is
well maintained with no safety/environmental hazards noted. The
agency is contracted with a pest control company for monthly
inspections and maintenance.
Conclusion No Violations
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503-2-f
Section The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the following
Description areas (f) Amount of financial support and how it is disbursed.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is withholding payment checks to coerce youth compliance with
contract requirements.
Investigation I participated in a PCU conference on 11/22/2022 with Social Worker 1
and agency representatives. The agency confirmed the withholding of
subsidy checks from participants as needed to coerce participant
compliance with their program contracts. It was reported the agency is
in the process of completing meetings with program staff to review
program policies and procedures and establish alternatives to this
practice.
I interviewed Complainant 1 at the agency/facility on 11/21/2022. The
complainant stated the agency would sometimes withhold participant’s
subsidy checks until the participants cleaned their rooms or completed
other responsibilities associated with their program contracts.
Complainant 1 indicated that when a participant was in compliance,
they were given their program subsidy check.
4

I completed an exit conference on 01/04/2023 with Administrator 1 who
acknowledged the practice of withholding participants subsidy
payments and reported the practice was no longer being used.
Administrator 1 indicated the agency was reevaluating program
practices to develop alternative methods of encouraging participants
compliance with their program contracts.
A copy of the program policies, procedures, and supporting documents
were received. There is no provision noted for withholding checks due
to negotiate compliance.
Analysis The policies/procedures received did not indicate/support the practice
of the agency withholding participants’ subsidy checks as a form of
enforcing contract compliance by the participants. However, interviews
with Complainant 1 and staff confirmed this had been a practice by the
agency as a means of enforcing program participation expectations.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the that
the current license status be continued.
